boardgame.name: Escape from Innsmouth (1st Edition)
boardgame.description:
From the back of the book:

"Innsmouth was once a prosperous trading town located on the north coast of Massachusetts. Early in the 19th century her great sailing ships traveled the world in search of trace and treasure.

A series of mishaps brought the town to the brink of financial ruin, but it was saved when Captain Obed Marsh discovered a secret source of gold among the islands of the South Pacific. Prosperity returned to Innsmouth, but only for a short time. The gold held a price that now, nearly a century later, has left the town a decaying hulk, its diseased citizenry mere shambling parodies of what were once people. Shunned by it's neigbours, Innsmouth slowly dies."

boardgame.name: Lure of the Expanse
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

You are a Rogue Trader, an explorer with a sacred mandate to venture beyond the limits of the Imperium in the name of the Emperor. Whether you live the life of an outlaw privateer, or as a scion of an ancient noble line, as a Rogue Trader you have the power and the tools to challenge all rivals for supreme control of the riches lurking in the uncharted reaches of space.

Now, you can bring the light of the Emperor to the darkest corners of the Koronus Expanse. Fantasy Flight Games is proud to announce the upcoming sourcebook for Rogue Trader, Lure of the Expanse!

Lure of the Expanse features three adventures set amongst the unexplored stars beyond the Imperium. Wealth and glory await those with the courage to venture into the farthest reaches of space.

In Eye of the Needle, your Explorers will travel to the perilous port of Footfall to learn of a dark prophecy of long-lost riches. In The Heathen Trail, the Explorers find themselves on the path of uncountable riches... but they must cross the wild tracts of the Heathen Stars. Threats abound, but can the Explorers transform danger into rewards? Finally, in The World Beyond, the Explorers discover the location of the legendary treasure world. Now, can they prevail against a host of enemies?

boardgame.name: Munchkin Fairy Dust Handbag Of Holding
boardgame.description:
User Summary

The Handbag of Holding was a promotional item originally given away by Steve Jackson Games during the August 2009 Gen Con in Indianapolis. It was reprinted in February 2012 and given away to people who spent $75 or more at the publisher's online store. Starting on March 6th, 2012 it briefly became available for purchase at the online store. So what had once been a highly collectible item due to its rarity, was now just another piece of Munchkin merchandise.

The handbag is a standard handbag, colored pink and with a picture of the Sparkly Good Fairy from the Munchkin Fairy Dust booster pack. As a handbag, it's nothing exceptional, but it also comes with a special rule for use in any Munchkin card game that includes the Munchkin Fairy Dust expansion. The rule allows you to take a card from the Fairy Dust deck's discard pile, once per game (see the corresponding board game version for details).

Part of the Munchkin series

boardgame.name: Classic BattleTech: Technical Readout 3075
boardgame.description:
In November 3067 the Second Star League disbanded. The Word of Blake - a splinter group of ComStar - had been on the verge of joining in fulfillment of ancient prophecies. Denied their dream, the Blakists sought to preserve the Star League against the follies of the Houses, but its fanaticism manifested this noble goal as the Jihad: a horrific war that has pitted every faction against each other and even themselves. Against such an anvil, new cutting edge machines of war are marched into the fire. The discovery of an ancient Hegemony Memory Core graphically showcases the desperation of the conflict, as primitive 'Mechs not seen on a battlefield since the dawn of 'Mech production over half a millennia ago once again appear.

Classic BattleTech Technical Readout: 3075 provides a comprehensive look at the latest machines of war debuting during the Jihad: from 'Mechs to battle armor, Support Vehicles to DropShips and more. In addition, a complete "Age of War" section covers the Terran Hegemony and each of the five Great Houses during the Age of War, including the very first BattleMechs produced by each faction and how such machines are starting to appear once more. Each military vehicle is illustrated in detail, accompanied by a description of its history, capabilities, game stats, and some of the unit's most famous pilots.

boardgame.name: Level II
boardgame.description:
Level II is a fast paced skirmish miniatures game, set in the future.
In the year 2222 mankind manages to devastate their home planet.
Nuclear fusion as well as manipulation of genes have become daily buisiness in this harsh world ruled by corporate groups.
Journeys to Mars have become possible and science is about to find a way to travel to the stars.

One of Level II's biggest strengths is, that it consists of a ruleset only. No miniatures come with this game!
This way a player may pick any of his miniatures and calculate their point costs referring to the extremely well elaborated and very fine tuned equipment list.
There are rules for about everything that has ever set it's metal or plastic foot on a futuristic war-torn gametable:
Humans, aliens, different kinds of humanoids, tough races, weak races, robots, androids, crafts, cannons, artillery, sabotage, special ammunition, cybernetics - everything you could wish for.
Even the equipment table basically covers everything "out there" - maybe you'll have to substitute sometimes some weapons (like a boltpistol with a common pistol), but you will be able to work with everything that you might find in the hands or at the belt of your miniature.

The rulebook covers the basic rules as well as experts' rules and campaign rules.

Even though Level II is designed for small scale skirmishes with only a couple of individual fighters per side, the rules don't prevent you from playing large scale combats as well.
In that case however players should have only a few different troop types, to keep combat simple.
For example on the one hand you could get about 50 - 100 light weighted fighters for 1000 points, but if you really spice them up, you may field less than 10 tough guys for the same value, too.

Level II uses an unique command system:
The army of a player is divided into several groups (one at least!) consisting of a number of fighters depending on the faction they are fighting for.
Each group gets one command (e.g. "advance"), represented by a chit placed at that group's position. Depending on that command, each fighter of that group may take up to two different actions (mostly moving + something different, like e.g. taking aim).
In order to change that command, certain conditions have to be met (roll versus a certain value with modifiers according to circumstances like e.g. groupleader killed or minimum distance not met) - if the roll fails the command is either changed later or even not at all.
Specialits may act according to their specialities whenever the player sees fit.

Level II plays very realistically: Most weapons kill an unarmoured human with one hit - just as in real life. This way you will have to be very careful with about everything:
How are you going to spend your points?
Where and (even mor important:) how are you going to move your fighters?
This way, Level II is a very tactical skirmish game where the skill and the experience of a player garantee a victory instead of lucky dierolls.

boardgame.name: Bible Wonders
boardgame.description:
From the front of the box: "The game of memory & morals."

Memory: The object of the game is to collect six gold coins. You travel around the board on one of six different roads. Movement occurs after turning over a picture that matches the picture next to the next space on the road. Each road is three pictures long and ends at an inn where you collect the gold coin. You may then choose to move to whichever road you want to travel next.

Morals: The pictures next to the roads show the consequences of 18 of Christ's miracles. The pictures that you turn over to match with them are the same scenes before the miracle occurred. The rules also contain a short story of "Malek's Journey" wherein he learns the secret of great wealth.

The game comes with instructions, a game board, 6 "Malek" sandal pieces, 6 flat leather purses on which you lay the coins, 18 match pictures, and 42 cardboard coins (6 coins in 7 colors).

"The Gamer's Handbook of the Marvel Universe is the complete last word on heroes, villains, and other characters of the Marvel Universe that players of the Marvel Super Heroes role-playing game have been looking for! Supplemented by data from the popular Official Handbook of the Marvel Universe, the Gamer's Handbook of the Marvel Universe has complete Marvel Super Heroes game statistics for hundreds of Marvel characters - the good, the bad and the in-between!

The pages of the Gamer's Handbook of the Marvel Universe are designed to be removed from the book for easy play. The pages are five hole punched so they can be organized in a binder. And each page includes complete background information, important facts, and complete stats - everything you need!

boardgame.name: Spies&Spooks: The Cold War Edition
boardgame.description:
Set in the 1980's, Spies&Spooks is a spy-themed strategy card game in which each player secretly assumes the role of one of eight spy characters. Each player also receives one of eight coded Assignments, which is decoded in the spy's Passport. The combination of the Secret Assignment with the Secret Identity determines how each player can win the game.
Secret Assignments are to gather specific Secret Cards (ie. Missile Secrets, Political Secrets, Computer Secrets, Trade Secrets etc) and smuggle them out of each game by combining them with various Smuggle Cards (Dead Drop, Diplomatic Pouch, Radio Transmission). Assignments carry varying rewards based upon their difficulty.
Depending on their Secret Identity traits, spies may also steal cards from each other, set bombs as traps, kill each other with Dagger Cards, expose other spies identities and/or assignments, or place them in detention in attempting to be the first spy to complete his or her Secret Mission.
Due to the many various combinations of Identities with Assignments, the game is constantly presenting new and different possibilities for players and has great replay value.
A player wins the game by being the first spy to complete his or her Secret Mission. Multiple hands can be played successively, constituting the Great Game.
Source: Publisher Statement

boardgame.name: Monsterpocalypse: Voltron – Defender of the Universe Battle Game
boardgame.description:
Press Release:
Expected release: July 2010 - Date subject to change.

Voltron: Defender of the Universe battle game includes everything two players need to stage epic battles between the forces of Voltron and the Galaxy Alliance and Prince Lotor and his robeast Lo-tron of the fiendish Drule Empire.

Includes 22 pre-painted plastic figures, including Voltron, 5 Voltron Lions, 5 Galaxy Garrison Cruisers, Lo-Tron, 1 Prince Lotor’s Command Ship, 4 Robeasts, and 5 Lo-Tron Force Skull Ships. The game will also include 1 double-sided play mat, 24 specialty dice, 4 status counters, and a full-color rulebook. Completely compatible with all current Monsterpocalypse series.

--
Kakaris Maelstrom adds:
Voltron: Defender of the Universe is a standalone game in the Monsterpocalypse game world, targeted at gamers who were hoping to see more "name brand" monsters in the game. The Voltron box offers players an excellent (and complete) way to get into the game but with some characters you're likely already familiar with. The game is also fully compatiable with other Monsterpocalypse miniatures and maps, so you'll no doubt start to see Terra Kahn vs. Voltron and such.

Voltron (and his nemesis Lo-Tron) are morphers, a type of monster whose Alpha form is made up of a series of unit-sized pieces. Voltron is unique in that previous morpher's Alpha forms were made up of 4 units, whereas Voltron and Lo-Tron are both 5 units. In addition, the battles are fought in space rather than on a traditional Monsterpocalypse city block.

Monsterpocalypse is a unexpectedly strategic CMG. Based in the world of kaiju (loosely translated from Japanese as ‘giant monster’), you'll control a monster and a legion of support units. You'll vie for control of critical board positions as you try to optimize your die pools. Then unleash your fury against your opponent's monster using a variety of power attacks, destroying a city block or two along the way.

boardgame.name: Caveman Curling
Kairn
碌冰野人
boardgame.description:
On an icy lake, two clans of prehistoric men clash in a match of Kairn, better known as Caveman Curling, this being an ancestor to the modern sport of curling. Players compete as individuals or are grouped into two clans, and they try to land their stones the closest to a target each round. On a player's turn he takes two actions:

• He launches a stone across the ice, flicking it with his finger toward the target on the other end of the game board.

• To improve the positioning of his stone or the chances of it staying in place, he can choose to use either a small or large hammer or a totem. With a hammer, the player moves the stone according to the size of the hammer. As for the totem, the player sets it on top of the stone; if the totem falls off the stone, the player can shoot it again on a later turn.

If your player or clan has one or more stones closer to the center of the target than the other clan, you score points. The first player/clan to collect six points wins.

A note about the different editions.

Caveman Curling (2012)
Kairn (2010)

There are significant production differences between Kairn and Caveman Curling, though the game play is almost identical between the two versions. Kairn (200 copies) was designed and self-published by Daniel Quodbach in 2010. Blackrock Editions and Scorpion Masque produced 1000 copies of Kairn and released it at Essen in 2011. Gryphon Games version of the game has yet to be produced, pending the conclusion of a current Kickstarter campaign that was organized to gauge demand for its version. Caveman Curling is scheduled for mass production in January, 2012, and to be released in late February, 2012. The first and only production copy of the Gryphon version will arrive in the US on December 14, 2011 and a video will be made showing the differences between Kairn and Caveman Curling.

boardgame.name: Flume (hex hex)
boardgame.description:
Hex hex Flume is a very simple game for two players, played on a hex hex board lined with a perimeter of green stones (or green, stone-sized stickers). Two players, Red and Blue, take turns adding stones of their own color to the board.

If you add a stone which forms 5 or 6 connections (adjacencies) with neighboring stones of any color (red, blue or green) you must add another stone to the board while it's still your turn. And so on. Your turn concludes when you add a stone which forms 4 or less connections with neighboring stones.

Certain move types are prohibited in hex hex Flume, unlike its sister game, square Flume, in which there are no prohibited move types.

The object is to have the majority of stones on the board.

boardgame.name: The World of Tales from the Crypt
boardgame.description:
From the back of the book

Welcome, kiddies, to my cozy Crypt. Have I got a story for you! It's time for another terror tale from your old pal, the Cryptkeeper — only this one stars you and your fiendish friends! It's a sickening little saga that promises to plunge you into malice, madness, murder and mayhem! So take a seat, boils and ghouls, the show's about to start... the credits are rolling... and it's curtains for you! Hehehehehehe!
From out of the Cryptkeeper's "die-brary" comes a roleplaying game guaranteed to provide frightseekers with twisted tales, sickening stabs at suspense, and chucnks of chilling charnel chatter. The Cryptkeeper is looking for someone to play with, so he's sending you and your players spiraling into a world of blood curdling horror, in search of sinister secrets, murderous mysteries, artifacts too awful to name, and the answers to his own "cryptic" riddles. The rules of his little game are simple: win... or die.

His players are people with dark secrets, hidden fears, and here and there a hint of madness. Dropped into strange settings (and sometimes other bodies), they must confront countless horrors, all the while at the mercy of the Cryptkeeper ... and the Cryptkeeper has no mercy.

Included in this WorldBook are tips on designing and running Tales from the Crypt adventures and campaigns, new background options, new skills, source material on the terrifying little town of Gainesford, adventure hooks, character templates, and a mini-adventure, "Circus of Souls".

You must have MasterBook to play this game.

Runner: The only piece allowed to touch the skull and score points. (mandatory)

Pole: Fighting piece able to block front field spaces.
Net: Catch enemy pieces
Hook: Pin enemy pieces

Cards are used for movement and to determine the outcome of fights.

boardgame.name: Berserker
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

Berserker introduces the "Third Force" into the In Nomine Satanis / Magna Veritas universe. The Third Force label designates occult forces independant of the forces of Good or Evil, such as beings from pre-christian pantheons. This sourcebook focuses on Vikings and Sorcerers.

Vikings are warriors who believe they have been recalled from Valhalla to take part in Ragnarok, the final battle between the Norse Gods and the Giants. They believe Demons to be the Giants, and Demons happily oblige (after all, viking warriors are less resilient than angels, and good target practice). The first chapters of the book contain everything needed to play a viking character, including character creation, powers, description of the pantheon, viking psychology and honor code...)

Sorcerers are human magicians, they seek knowledge and power by summoning angels or demons and attempting to bind them. Sorcerers are meant to be NPCs, but the rules cover everything needed to play one, including summon rules and some other spells.

The book ends with two scenarios: "Pour qui sonne le gland" is set during the battle for Berlin in 1945, the characters' goal is to eliminate Adolf Hitler. It can be played by angel, demon or viking player characters. "Qui veut la bite de Roger Rapeau" has the players (angels or demons) investigate a series of strange murders.

boardgame.name: Go Goal! Ole! Tournament
boardgame.description:
In Go Goal! Ole! Tournament each player contols a team of five footballers. On their turn each players can spend up to one action for each footballer they control, not including the goalkeeper.

That action may be to move the footballer 1 space in any direction, to tackle another player, to pass the ball to another footballer or empty space, play an SFC (Special Function Card) or shoot for goal.

To tackle, each player rolls a D12. If the attacker wins, the two footballers exchange places and the attacker gains possession of the ball.

To pass the ball to another player or space, you just need to have line of sight to the space you're aiming for and it needs to be in a straight line (like the queen's movement in chess). You then simply place the ball on that player or space.

Each player recieves 3 Special Funcion Cards in each half of the game which can be played at any point during your turn.

To shoot at goal, each footballer figure has a spring-loaded knee joint which you pull back and release. This is where the dexterity aspect of the game comes in.

There are 90 of these super-quick turns in a standard game, and whoever has scored the most goals by the end is the winner.

From the description on the box:
Go Goal! Ole! Tournament is a five-a-side football board game, combining the technique of shooting a ball and strategic thinking of a board game that gives players to enjoy and feel the excitement of a real football match.

Contents:
1x Football Field
4x Footballs
8x Footballer Figures with Stands
2x Goalkeeper Figures with Stands
2x Goal Posts with 4x Goal Screws
1x Score and Round Counter
25x Special Function Cards

1x VCD/DVD Game Demo

4x Black & White Manuals (Danmark, Norge, Suomi & Sverige)

boardgame.name: Too Bad!
boardgame.description:
Description from BoardgameNews.com:

Too Bad! is a perfect information game in which players want to be the first to bring all their dice home. Each player has dice that start with the face-up numbers 1-4, with the 4s in the starting spot farthest from home, the 3s in the next starting spot, and so on.

On a turn, a player moves one of her dice as many spaces as the sum of all the dice sharing the same space. Land on a "slip & flip" slide, and you knock off any dice in the middle of the slide, while flipping your die upside-down at the end of the ride. Thus, a 4 becomes a 3, a 3 becomes a 2, and so on.

boardgame.name: Drugo: the ultimate drug education game
boardgame.description:
Each player has a card (similar to bingo) with drug "lifestyle" references
in each space, such as Cocaine, Police department, Illegal, Sedative, etc.
The caller has a stack of cards which he turns over one at a time and reads
the statement on it. Then players must determine what the proper response or
definition is, and place a token on that space.
A winner is determined when a card ihas every spot filled, and checked to be legal.
A variation for scoring is similar to bingo, with many variations, such as 4 corners,
5 in a row, 5 in a diagonal being a winner. There is also a master sheet
which the caller places the cards on when called, so that later when checking
a card, the person can figure out if they got a question wrong.

40 playing cards, 75 calling clues, Drugo Fact Sheet, Directions,
Checking Master Chart, Instruction sheet, and whole lot of pink
markers.

boardgame.name: Batailles de Westeros
Batallas de Poniente
Le Battaglie di Westeros
Battles of Westeros
Bitwy Westeros
Die Schlachten von Westeros
维斯特洛
boardgame.description:
Unfurl the banners of the Great Houses of Westeros! To secure power in the Seven Kingdoms and to ensure the survival of their lines, the Houses of Westeros each follow very different paths. Some forge strategic alliances, some create complex political intrigues, and still others use deceit and betrayal. But there is no more direct or lasting path to power than taking to the field of battle.

In Battles of Westeros, two players recreate the military conflicts set in George R.R. Martin’s A Song of Ice and Fire series, taking part in battles directly from the books... or designing their own. In this epic board game of battlefield tactics, players control either House Stark, the wards of Winterfell who have called their hearty allies to defend their honor and lands, or House Lannister, an aggressive force funded by Casterly Rock’s endless supply of gold.

Battles of Westeros is played over a series of included scenarios, called battles. Each of these has a battle plan that dictates the formation of the map (called the battlefield), starting positions of each House’s units, starting resources, special rules, and victory conditions for the game session. A battle is played over several rounds, with each round consisting of alternating player turns. The goals a player needs to accomplish to win a game of Battles of Westeros can vary (some battles require players to earn a certain number of victory points, while other battles require a player to take and hold strategic positions on the battlefield), but this collection of available scenarios, along with the ability to make your own exciting battles with the double-sided map board and over thirty map overlays, gives Battles of Westeros a wealth of replayability!

Battles of Westeros also offers plenty of strategic complexity, resulting in a satisfying number of compelling choices in every game. For example, each player has a special randomized Leadership Deck, consisting of unique tactics and abilities; this deck will change based on the scenario being played and characters present. Is Jaime Lannister on the battlefield? If you draw the appropriate Leadership Card, he can order nearby troops to aggressively rush their opponents! Is Eddard Stark guiding his forces into battle? Special flanking maneuvers enter your Leadership Deck, to potentially be drawn into your hand.

Battles of Westeros also features a level of realism that immerses you in the most significant conflicts of the War of the Five Kings. Each plastic figure base, which holds your infantry, archer, cavalry, and kennelmaster units, has a slot for a banner pole – a small flag-bearing attachment. The plastic banners that attach to each unit bear the crest of that unit’s house, and their orientation on the pole indicates at a glance whether that unit has been ordered yet. In addition to the intuitive and useful game effect this provides (differentiating the units you’ve activated from those you haven’t), the sight of your army’s banners spread impressively across the gorgeously designed game board will give you the sense that you are the clever Tywin Lannister, Lord of Casterly Rock... or the stoic Robb Stark, with his direwolf Grey Wind at his side!

Cinderella, Ariel, Snow White, Aurora and Belle are racing to get ready and get to the Ball! Each Princess needs her invitation, her flowers, her crown, her dress and her shoes before she can go to the castle to meet her handsome Prince...

Players use a colored spinner to move their Princess along a colored path where some squares indicate one of the items the players are collecting. Items are represented by puzzle pieces that, when collected and assemble, form a picture of each of the 5 Disney Princesses in the game. When a player has collected all 5 items for their Princess and have reached the end of the path, they can meet up with their prince by getting the correct color on the spinner.

Sleepyhead
boardgame.description: Schlafmütze is a card game of set collection, sly hand movements, and social observation for 3-7 players ages 5 and up. Players try to collect 4 matches of a drowsy character. The last person with cards left in hand is the sleepyhead and must take the "sleeping goblin" token. Source: user summary

boardgame.name: Questions pour un Champion
boardgame.description:
Questions pour un Champion is a French game based on the TV show of the same name. Played from 3 to 5 players it is a game that tests both your knowledge and your reflex.

In the first round all the players are obliged to answer questions by pushing a special button before anyone else does. The goal is to score 9 points which takes a player to the second round. The player that didn't reach 9 points when everyone else did is eliminated.

In the second round each remaining player chooses one of four proposed subjects and has to answer questions related to it. The maximum score here is 4 points (for 4 consecutive correct answers). The best two players go through to the final.

In the last round the two remaining players are face to face, having to find the answer for some long questions read by the presenter. The players may score 4, 3, 2 or 1 point, based on the number of information given by the presenter. The first player to score 9 points is the winner.

(from MMP's website :)

The ASL Journal #8 is a 60-page magazine of nothing but articles, scenarios, and support materials for Advanced Squad Leader.

The Table of Contents for ASL Journal #8 looks like this:


Carl Nogueira shows you the proper way to grease the treads of your tank in Crosstown Traffic — a detailed look at the rules for Vehicular Overrun.
Mark Pitcavage teaches new ASL players how to lose some of that new player shine in The Agony of Defeat.
Lars Thuring and Tuomo Lukkari take us on a tour of the upcoming Finn module Hakkaa Päälle!
Matt Shostak provides a detailed scenario analysis of scenario J74 Priests on the Line
David Olie shows you what you can do at setup with all that cool stuff you get on your scenario card in A Place For Your Stuff.
Jim Stahler gives us a detailed breakdown of the scenarios in Turning The Tide.
Ian Daglish provides designer's notes on the conception and birth of Action Pack 4: Normandy 1944.
Bret Hildebran and J.R. Tracy take us on a detailed look at their defensive setups for scenario J113 Maczek Fire Brigade


And there are 16 ASL scenarios:

boardgame.name: MindStorm
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

Mindstorm adds psionic powers and renegade angels and demons to INS/MV.

Psis are humans who have developed mental powers. They're not affiliated to Good or Evil, they have their own goals and most of them are employed by corporations called "Trusts". Renegades are angels or demons who decide to quit, and either join the other side of the Great Game or just try to be left alone (which won't happen, since neither Archangels nor Demon Prince like traitors).

The book contains all the rules needed to create and play a psi character, rules for trusts and the high-tech gear they develop, a chapter describing the consequences of becoming a renegade, two scenarios ("Turlututu, chapeau pointu, tu l'as dans le c..." and "Basile, il y a un éléphant dans ma cathédrale"), and a chapter describing compatibilities between the different forces of the game (angels, demons, psis, voodoo, vikings, sorcerers...)

boardgame.name: Il Etait Une Fois
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

Il était une fois contains scenarios and gamemaster aids about Space-Time Continuum travel.

After a short explanation of time travelling and parallel universes and a presentation of the means of travel used by the different factions, the book offers four scenarios to take the players to different times and places:

- "Alouette, gentille alouette" has a team of angel characters sent to protect Joan of Arc

- "Accroche-toi aux clous, j'enlève l'échelle" asks a team of angels to make sure the crucifixion of Jesus happens

- "Reviens Georges, j'ai les mêmes à la maisons" (for demons or viking characters) is about saving the last dragon and the last fey folk from the armies of Georges, Archangel of Purification

- "Le Pouvoir Derrière La Croix" (also for demons) has the players take part in an Inquisition tribunal in 1322 in order to save a jewish merchant

The book also contains three new Archangels (Catherine Archangel of Women, Georges Archangel of purification, and Jesus Archangel of God - yes, you get stats for Jesus).

boardgame.name: The Metabarons Universe Guide
boardgame.description:
User Summary (derived from product text and Introduction):

Fans of The Incal and The Metabarons, rejoice! For the first time anywhere, Alexander Jodorowski, co-creator of The Incal and The Metabaron, reveals never-before-seen details about the amazing universe of the Metabaron. Learn the secret histories of the Human Empire, the Shabda-Oud Sisterhood, and the parallel universes that surround our own. Explore the alliances and conspiracies that hold the Empire together (and threaten to tear it apart). Learn why the Necro-Dream is so dangerous, and how close Mankind stands to ultimate oblivion.

The Universe Guide sheds new light on many aspects of daily life in the Human Empire, and delves into the structure and organization of the Imperial Government (the Senate, the Noble Houses, the Techno-Pontificate, the Ekonomat, and the Maganats), the Mentreks, the Endogaurd, the Shabda-Oud, the Metabaron, and the Colonials. Also covered are secret societies, cults and religions, notable planets, The Golden Palace of the Emperoress, the Imperial Navy, and the limitations and hazards of hyperspace travel.

Extensive sections on the history of the universe include a time-line of events for the "The Incal" and "The Metabarons," tracing the growth of the empire and the family of the Metabaron. Players of The Metabarons Roleplaying Game will find a wealth of new character templates and professions, new rules for aliens and mutants, new weapons and cybernetics, a detailed anatomy of a typical Endocity, new vehicles and robots, resources for creating exciting galaxy-spanning adventures, and at long last, the hidden secrets of the Metabunker, the invincible fortress of the Metabarons.

The first edition of the Metabarons Universe Guide was published (in French) in 2001. The English translation for the abridged .PDF version was provided by Diane Bertrand, Justin Kelly, and Joan Wilchins. Thank you for your work!

The .PDF version includes the following note.

Note to Readers:
The Abridged PDF (English) version of the Universe Guide was created from the original electronic files. Selected images and text were left out or modified, and the page layout was modified to reduce file size and production time. This electronic document was conceived as a relatively inexpensive means for people to get information about the Metabarons Universe that was previously unavailable. This PDF requires the Metabarons Roleplaying Game Rule Book to play.

boardgame.name: Crystal Core: Battle for Nih'ki
Nih'ki: The Crystal Core War
boardgame.description:
From the designer's website:

Crystal Core: Battle for Nih'ki is a tactical wargame for two to four players.

Players battle for control of various objective zones, using one of four factions: the Daiseep, Humans, Khelons, and Saahrai. Each force is commanded by one or two Heroes, and features a number of Troopers and/or Vehicles. In the advanced game mode, players can select armoury cards to provide their units or their whole force with unique abilities.

Crystal Core features simulated parallel play through the use of command cards, which are selected simultaneously by each player, and define what actions are available for that round. Players must devise a plan for each round, and execute it with a focus on army-cohesion and maneuvering for prime position to achieve victory.

The game also provides a superior wargaming experience by eliminating several of the upkeep actions associated with wargames, including model-per-model movement, excessive dice rolls, and army wide actions, thereby providing maximum entertainment in a modest timeframe.

boardgame.name: Essentia
boardgame.description:
Far away, in a land called Essentia, two Orders of spell casters have fought for the territory’s possession through the years. Sworn enemies, the Wizards of Dawn and the Sorcerers of Twilight strive for their opponents’ end in every battle. But the number of magicians is small and their life is priceless, so they do not fight on their own but by means of golems under their command.

These battles are carried out on a strange zone where a special magic named essence provides the golems with new powers. That place, called The Changing Land, consists of several different terrains: plains, plateaus, rocks, forests and mountains. There also exist other weird zones, such as springs and circles of essence. Every magic terrain gives a certain magic power to whom tread on it so that it allows them to move or attack in different ways.

Today, one more struggle is about to begin. A skilled wizard of Dawn and a clever sorcerer of Twilight are the chosen ones to handle the golems to solve the battle.

The game includes:

- Organic cotton case (Format 1).
- A4 flexible pad board.
- 28 printed and laser-cut tiles.
- 16 dark onyx laser-cut acrylic golems.
- 16 translucent white laser-cut acrylic golems.
- Rulesheet.

boardgame.name: Consensus Music Edition
boardgame.description:
Description from BoardgameNews

Consensus Music Edition uses the same game play as the other Consensus titles released by Mindlogic: Ten things are laid out on the gameboard – song titles in this case of this game – then players are presented with a category, such as "Song most likely to be on Bill Clinton's iPod," and secretly choose one thing that they think best represents the category. If you match someone else's answer, you scoot ahead on the path to victory. All things chosen by a player, whether matched or not, are removed from the gameboard and replaced with new cards. The first player to reach the end of the path wins.

boardgame.name: L'esprit d'escalier
boardgame.description:
Designer's Summary:

L'esprit d'escalier is a free-form dialog-driven role playing game. There is no game master, and the game introduces a new role in game mechanics: the scene owner. The role of scene owner is passed around the table clockwise or anti-clockwise.

The scene owner sets a scene between themselves and the next player in line to be scene owner, in which a conflict is covered. After the scene the second player acts out a monologue, detailing what he or she should have said and done.

boardgame.name: Strychnine IV
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

Strychnine IV describes a solar system where angels, demons and vikings have been at war for the most part of the last 5000 years.

Each planet has a detailed description and a scenario.

Haven I used to be an agricultural colony before being destroyed by a spaceship crash. Now it's an uninhabitable mass grave said to be haunted (but still fought over by zealous Stella Vaticanum officers and demons).

Virus II is a green planet, but its flora doesn't like the idea of offworlders and technology and is quite capable of defending itself. The planet is occupied by feral humans, and a few demons and angels sent to study the anti-technology properties of the planet who have become stranded.

Cryo III is an ice planet settled by vikings who have turned it into a fortress.

Strychnine IV, the poison planet, is a permanent warzone. It used to be an industrial world, but thousands of years of pollution and warfare have turned it into a desolate place. Neither Stella Vaticanum nor Dunkle Reik has succeeded in taking control of the planet, but each keep sending troops in the hope of finally breaking the stalemate. It has become a favorite testing ground for new weapons and tactics for each faction of the conflict.

Hellraiser is a marooned Dunkle Reik spaceship orbiting the sun.It was a prototype battleship (five times bigger than any other ship) that was half destroyed when a Stella Vaticanum battleship rammed it to prevent its escape. Both factions are still fighting inside the two ships, and the environment has given birth to strange mutated fungus in the former hydroponics labs, and undead creatures roam the ship freely, unhindered by the lack of air or radiation shielding.

The book also includes a some new equipment and creatures.

boardgame.name: ICONS Superpowered Roleplaying
boardgame.description:
From the publisher's website:

What kid raised in recent generations hasn’t pretended to be a superhero at some point: worn a cape, flown around, bounced imaginary bullets or shot blasts of power from hands or eyes? Why not? After all, the superhero is the perfect modern fantasy: powerful, respected, and loved by the public, but with a message of responsibility, duty, truth, and justice that appeals to parents as well as kids. In countless comic books (and now graphic novels), cartoons, and live-action television shows and films, superheroes continue to thrill and capture our imagination while also celebrating some of our better qualities. Who wouldn’t want to be a hero?

With ICONS, you can be!

Steve Kenson, the designer of the best-selling Mutants & Masterminds delivers a superpowered new role-playing game, inspired by the fast-playing old-school games and the new generation of narrative role-play! Within its pages are complete rules for character creation, abilities and powers, random adventure generation, a rogue's gallery of villains, a complete adventure and all the superheroic action you can handle!

boardgame.name: Final Stand
boardgame.description:
From the Game's Introduction:

Final Stand is a game where you play a group of martial artists fighting for their lives. It is meant to be light, action-packed, and fun. Final Stand isn't heavy on setting. It's about cool characters and kick-ass action.

User Summary:

Final Stand is a free, independently published RPG that models martial arts movies. Game play is divided into combat encounters and "fluff" scenes, which are any non-combat portion of the game. The game includes few mechanics for "fluff" scenes, but does include a diceless, purely karma-based skill system for resolving basic non-combat conflicts. Combat, however, is resolved using three dice pools (kicking, punching and throwing), successes from which are spent on various moves available to each character according to martial arts forms chosen at character generation.

boardgame.name: Isla Tetra
boardgame.description:
(now available as Isla Tetra 2 - please check BGG page)

The first game from Will Sargent's Solway Games uses a colourful new puzzle system to create essential inventory items which can be used to explore the mysterious island, ISLA TETRA.

The same colourful grids are built to earn Exploration, Health and Fishing actions, making for a puzzling castaway adventure of the like never seen before.

You might think you can get by simply walking the sun-kissed sands, soaking up the sun, but leave your island escape plan too late and you'll find events back home have taken a turn for the worse: As the months tick by, the search for your crashed plane is eventually called off, your job is readvertised, and your car has been sold to keep up with the bills. After two years of waiting, your family holds a memorial service and your partner is now returning to a social life as a single person. You might be a great survivor, but at what cost?

Each turn players can beachcomb for useful items such as rope, old bits of wire and driftwood. You might even find a pilot's hat or laminated crash instructions washed up from the azure, salty brine. These pieces of flotsam and jetsam are shown on 52 professionally printed cards and represented by brightly coloured, chunky 3D shapes which can be linked neatly together on your individual player mat to build items essential for survival.

Players must strike a balance between plundering the island’s resources for points while ensuring they’re not last off the island. Finish too low down on the time-track and you'll accrue penalty points which could rob you of victory.

It's all about strategy, and fun puzzle solving. Some of your inventory items can only be built using a single colour, while others allow two or all three. Also, some grids are larger than others, taking longer to build, some are small and awkward to fit all the available shapes into.

Upgrades can give you more playing power, such as extra card swaps and extra jokers; longer explore moves; greater fish catches. Which to go for first? It's up to you to try the many different combinations.

To start, you are only allowed to build two items at a time so think carefully... whittle away by the fire at base camp, or set out deep into the island in search of vines and timber to help strengthen your small raft, ready for the final ordeal across raging seas...

source: from publisher: Solway Games

boardgame.name: Progressive Mancala
boardgame.description:
Progressive Mancala was invented by Ralf Gering on September 3, 2004, in Bad Breisig, Germany. The game uses a rule which reminds of Progressive Chess.

The game was implemented for online play at games.wtanaka.com on January 28, 2010.

Rules

Progressive Mancala is played on a one-rank mancala board which numbers eleven holes. Initially there are five stones in each hole. There is also a common goal which is adjacent to the central hole of the board. Both players sit on the same side of the board in front of it. One player is called West, the other East.

East starts to the game and plays from right to left. West sows from left to right.

On each turn a player empties a hole and then distributes its contents into the following holes, one by one, in his direction. If he reaches the end of the board, he continues to distribute the stones by first dropping a stone into the Goal, then into the holes starting from the opposite end of the board. That is, he circles around the board.

If the last stone is dropped into a non-empty hole, its contents (including the last distributed stone) are picked up and then distributed as usual in multi-lap games.

The move ends if the last stone is dropped into an empty hole or the goal.

For each move that a player has terminated in an empty hole, his enemy must make a bonus move (bonus moves are compulsory).

If the last stone is dropped into the goal, the player captures its contents including the last distributed stone. The captured stones are stored. Dropping the last stone into the goal never results in a bonus move for the opponent.

The player who captured most stones is declared the winner. Draws are impossible because the sum of all stones is odd.

Expert Variant

Good players may take a board which has 17 holes. Again, there are five stones in each hole at the start of the game.

boardgame.name: The Great City, Cold Crypts
boardgame.description:
From the publisher:

As you descend the wide marble stairs, the temperature drops dramatically. The air turns frigid, stinging your throat and lungs with its iciness as your breath condenses, sticking to the cold, granite walls in foggy crystals. You have entered the legendary Cold Crypts beneath Castle Atregan. Quickly you recall dozens of tales about the lightless world of ancient and terrible hauntings — how its darkness remains unblemished, for merely lighting the passages is a sin. Whispered tales come to mind of unknown fates that have befallen those mortals daring to transgress its sanctity without the proper rituals. You hope these stories are only to fill the curiosity of petulant children with dread, or to dissuade would-be thieves.

Beneath the castle Atregan lies a massive ancestral crypt, a labyrinthine tangle of thousands of tombs of ancient nobles, priests, and seers. Tales abound that the sins of centuries of Atregan rule drive restless spirits from their graves to wander the hallways in malevolent mockery.

This product expands 0one's Blueprints: The Great City, Castle Ward and the related adventure The Road to Revolution 5: The Usurpers.
